newsitem.title: INDIA: India's Grasim faces shrinking margins.
newsitem.headline: India's Grasim faces shrinking margins.

text.p: The profit growth of diversified Grasim Industries Ltd in 1997/98 (April-March) is likely to be hurt by shrinking margins, analysts said on Wednesday.

"With bleak business prospects in its cement and steel businesses, we do not see the company's performance improving significantly in the first half of 1997/98," Rajesh Mayani, analyst at James Capel B&K said.
An analyst at a European securities firm said weak commodity prices would hamper profit growth at Grasim, flagship firm of the Aditya Birla group.
World prices of viscose staple fibre (VSF), a textile raw material, had risen 5-8 percent recently but Grasim had little room to raise its own prices due to sluggish domestic demand, analysts said.
Grasim is one of the world's biggest producers of VSF. It also makes cement, sponge iron and caustic soda.
However, the company said it expected an improved performance in 1997/98.
"The company expects better performance in 1997/98 both in terms of sales turnover and profitability," Grasim said.
"The optimism stems from the company's multipronged efforts towards modernisation, expansion and taking care of infrastructural contingencies across major divisions," it said in a statement.
The firm said on Wednesday its net profits fell to 2.74 billion rupees ($76.62 million) in the year ended March 31, 1997, from 3.32 billion rupees a year ago.
Analysts attributed the fall to poor demand for VSF, cement and sponge iron, as well as production disruptions and higher costs.
Consensus estimates in a Reuters poll of analysts had placed net profit at 2.99 billion rupees for 1996/97.
Profits would have been even worse if not for 600 million rupees in capital gains arising from the sale of investments, an analyst with a European securities firm said.
Analysts had expected income from other sources to be halved to one billion rupees but the capital gains boosted it to 1.53 billion rupees in 1996/97. Other income was 2.11 billion rupees in 1995/96.

Shortages of water and electricity hampered the company's operations. VSF output fell to 155,385 tonnes in 1996/97 from 162,470 tonnes a year earlier due to a water shortage caused by late monsoon rains, which resulted in the loss of 46 production days.
In response, the company has set up a reservoir at its Nagda plant in central Madhya Pradesh state.
VSF accounts for 60 percent of Grasim's profits and 40 percent of total sales.

Grasim expects in the third quarter of 1997 to commission a 30,000 tonnes-a-year VSF plant in western Gujarat state. The plant will eventually have a capacity to produce 60,000 tonnes annually and will generate all of its own power.
Production of cement rose 25.4 percent to 4.1 million tonnes in 1996/97 from 3.27 million tonnes a year ago, but price realisations were lower.
Analysts expect little improvement in cement realisations during 1997/98 because of oversupply, especially in the regions where Grasim's plants are located.
Output of sponge iron jumped 103.3 percent to 706,510 tonnes against 347,513 tonnes in a shutdown-marred 1995/96. Analysts said the plant's capacity was 750,000 tonnes.

Grasim raised $90 million and $100 million, respectively, in 1992 and 1994 through global depositary receipt issues overseas, but a third issue for $125 million had to be called off in 1996/97 due to poor market conditions.
